speaker: grahampaige
content: Welcome everyone. Let's begin discussion on: Agenda Item No. 3.3: Technology Plan - The board will review a proposal to expand digital learning access by providing Chromebooks to every high school student. This initiative is estimated to cost $10,000 annually for devices, maintenance, and licensing. The program is designed to ensure equitable access to technology, support blended learning, and prepare students with digital skills for college and career readiness.. Who would like to start?

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: I can kick it off. I want to commend staff members for crafting this plan to bridge digital divides within our district. What is especially impressive is the focus on equity through offering Chromebook opportunities for all high school students. Could you please elaborate how we're going to ensure equal device distribution across different socio-economic backgrounds and home internet situations that may create potential barriers? This consideration should be integral as we explore these next steps. I want to hear more details regarding ongoing maintenance and support infrastructure. How do we plan to keep such devices running in classrooms throughout their lifespan? And what are some potential avenues for securing funding outside our district budget for sustainability after a couple years down the line. Finally, are there any plans in place for making devices accessible and useful not just inside schools but also from homes that have unreliable Wi-Fi connectivity. Do we know where those areas exist in the region to get creative on finding ways to serve children lacking reliable home connections?  Thank you for your thoroughness so far. As long as we prioritize support structures, resources, and careful planning around deployment, then I believe this effort holds vast potential for addressing disparities while developing valuable modern tech skills.

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: One area that came up for me, during pandemic schooling was, of course, lack of availability, right, and trying to find out who did not have computers at home, but the other thing that happened is we realized, well, let's say you have a computer at home but if you don't have internet connection it doesn't help that much, so the whole connectivity piece is crucial here. How are we going to address these issues about ensuring that they're not just devices per se, because otherwise,  devices alone might still mean no connection and they need that too to do homework, complete assignments online and learn effectively. In terms of partnerships, there's already been an AT&T grant available. There were hotspots made available to families last year which actually really helped alleviate the problem quite a bit for many families. Now you mentioned how else could you potentially secure funding. Well the E-rate system should cover some costs like the network infrastructure upgrades, so we'll be able to take advantage of federal e-rate dollars to offset some maintenance costs. We've had quite good fortune with corporate partners helping us address those issues so certainly something we can look into in terms of the infrastructure of maintaining them in the long run. That said though the current pandemic funds might allow us flexibility. As we think about all these, you know there's the one-time payment and then there's the annual recurrent ones, how can we best use the available funding without burdening our local budget or relying on just grants, given that those sometimes come and go. Another potential area for thought could lie in how local government entities partner together. For instance, they could contribute to setting up network connectivity infrastructure so students can access reliable internet services when at home. How could we make those devices accessible and useful even outside of school, not only just by setting up the infrastructure but even beyond that? So that is another important part of the equation, and that has to be worked into our project goals since the device itself wouldn't magically solve these differences in connectivity by themselves.

speaker: davidoberg
content: Thank you both Jon and Katrina for your thoughtful remarks. By tackling these complex challenges collectively, we can ensure every student benefits from this technological investment. What suggestions do others have for innovative approaches to maintain digital equity in our district?
